data.title: All 50 Yul Brynner Movies (in Order)
data.meta_description: Get ready to journey through the illustrious career of the remarkable Yul Brynner in this compelling movie roundup. From his epic performances in iconic films like “The King and I” and “The Ten…
data.text:
Mildred Waters

·

Follow

19 min read

·

Mar 18, 2024

--

Get ready to journey through the illustrious career of the remarkable Yul Brynner in this compelling movie roundup. From his epic performances in iconic films like “The King and I” and “The Ten Commandments, “ to his captivating roles in lesser-known gems, this article delves into the versatile world of Yul Brynner, showcasing his diverse talents and undeniable charm. So, sit back, relax, and let’s embark on this unforgettable cinematic adventure.

As an Amazon™ Associate, we earn from qualifying purchases.

1. The Ten Commandments (1956)

Experience the epic tale of redemption and courage with “The Ten Commandments”, a cinematic masterpiece released in 1956. Starring Charlton Heston, Yul Brynner, and Anne Baxter, this film follows the life of Moses, a prince of Egypt raised in Pharaoh’s household but eventually discovering his Hebrew roots. Guided by a divine mission, Moses embarks on the journey to bring freedom to his people from slavery.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

2. Anastasia (1956)

In “Anastasia” (1956), an opportunistic businessman and his comrades conspire to pass off an amnesiac woman claiming to be Anastasia Nikolaevna Romanova, the Grand Duchess of Russia, as the real Anastasia after her family’s tragic death. The mysterious impostor convincingly takes on the role, even fooling the biggest skeptics, including the Dowager Empress Maria Feodorovna, who believes the woman is her granddaughter. As the impostor engages with those who remember the real Anastasia, the lines between truth and deception begin to blur, leaving open questions as to the identity of the woman and a tantalizing mystery of her survival.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

3. The King and I (1956)

Experience the enchanting tale of a widow who becomes a governess to the King of Siam’s children in the beloved 1956 musical “The King and I. “ Set in 1862, the story follows Anna Leonowens (played by Deborah Kerr) as she embarks on a journey to Siam with her son Louis (Rex Thompson). Upon their arrival, they are welcomed by the opulent Palace of the King, but not everyone is thrilled with Anna’s presence.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

4. Houseboat (1958)

Houseboat is a heartwarming 1958 comedy-drama that tells the tale of a widower, his three young children, and an Italian nanny as they navigate life and love aboard a run-down houseboat in Washington, D. C. This overlooked masterpiece features the iconic duo of Cary Grant and Sophia Loren, delivering delightful performances and captivating the audience with their charming chemistry.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

5. The Buccaneer (1958)

Experience the thrilling adventure of “The Buccaneer, “ a 1958 epic drama directed by Anthony Quinn and written by Jesse Lasky Jr. , Bernice Mosk, and Jeanie Macpherson. This gripping film, set during the War of 1812, follows the story of Louisiana pirate Jean Lafitte, played by Yul Brynner, who teams up with the Americans to defend their precious city, New Orleans. British forces are relentless in their pursuit of the city, with a powerful war fleet on the attack.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

6. The Brothers Karamazov (1958)

The Brothers Karamazov, released in 1958, is a dramatization of Russian writer Fyodor Dostoevsky’s classic novel of the same name. The film takes place in 1870s Russia and centers around the proud Karamazov family. As the family grapples with a gambling debt and personal tragedies, it also delves into the realm of the psychic as the characters grapple with their own darkest secrets.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

7. Solomon and Sheba (1959)

Solomon and Sheba, released in 1959, is a captivating drama, history, and romance film set in ancient Israel. King Solomon, played by Yul Brynner, faces numerous challenges as he ascends to the throne, including threats from his jealous brother Adonijah, the Egyptian Pharaoh, and the cunning Queen of Sheba, portrayed by Gina Lollobrigida.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

8. The Journey (1959)

In “The Journey, “ set amidst the tumultuous Hungarian Revolution of 1956, a resolute British woman named Susan (Deborah Kerr) and her freedom fighter lover, David (Yul Brynner), join forces with a group of Westerners in an attempt to escape the oppressive Soviet Union. As the revolution unfolds and the Soviets attempt to crush the rebellion, Susan becomes the captivating obsession of an enigmatic Communist officer, Vlad (Jason Robards).

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

9. The Sound and the Fury (1959)

The Sound and the Fury” (1959) is a gripping drama that captures the essence of a Southern aristocratic family grappling with the dissolution of their once-prominent clan. Set during the tumultuous period of Mississippi’s Southern Reconstruction in the post-American Civil War era, the story delves into the disintegration of faith, fortune, and respect, as the characters struggle to adapt and maintain their social status.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

10. Once More, with Feeling! (1960)

Once More, with Feeling! “ is a delightful 1960 romantic comedy directed by Stanley Donen. Yul Brynner stars as Victor Fabian, a musical virtuoso with a quirky personality controlled by his loving wife. Tragedy strikes when she finds out about a fiery young pianist, and she leaves him, causing his once-promising career to spin out of control.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

11. The Magnificent Seven (1960)

The Magnificent Seven” is an enthralling 1960 film that brings together seven skilled gunfighters to defend a Mexican village from tyrannical bandits. Set in the rugged Western terrain, the ensemble cast breathes life into the tale of friendship, showdowns, and mercenary work.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

12. Goodbye Again (1961)

Goodbye Again” is a captivating drama-romance film from 1961, set in Paris, France. Ingrid Bergman stars as a successful business woman who finds herself at a crossroads in her current relationship — a philandering lover.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

13. Taras Bulba (1962)

Taras Bulba” is a thrilling historical drama set in 16th-century Ukraine, where the oppressed cossacks and the ruling Polish overlords must momentarily unite for a common cause: to defend their land from the destructive Turkish invaders. Directed by J.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

14. Escape from Zahrain (1962)

Escape from Zahrain” is a thrilling adventure film that takes viewers deep into the arid, treacherous world of Arab terrorism. Set in the fictional country of Zahrain, a group of individuals, whose allegiance to the rebel cause remains unclear, embark on an intense journey fraught with danger and uncertainty.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

15. Flight from Ashiya (1964)

Experience the thrilling adventure of Flight from Ashiya, set in the picturesque landscape of Japan, 1964. Directed by Michael Anderson, this drama film follows a dedicated flight crew led by Yul Brynner, Richard Widmark, and George Chakiris.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

16. Morituri (1965)

Morituri, released in 1965, is an action-packed drama and thriller set during World War Two. The story follows a war pacifist who is blackmailed into posing as an SS officer with the mission to disable the scuttling explosives on a freighter carrying rubber cargo set to be captured by the Allies.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

17. The Poppy Is Also a Flower (1966)

The Poppy Is Also a Flower (1966) is an action-packed crime drama that delves into the dangerous world of heroin smuggling. Taking the audience on a thrilling journey, United Nations narcotics agents tirelessly hunt down heroin shipments from the Afghanistan-Iran border to the main European distributor.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

18. Return of the Seven (1966)

In “Return of the Seven, “ two surviving members of the original Magnificent Seven, Chris (Yul Brynner) and Vin, assemble a new group of gun-slingers to protect a handful of Mexican towns from a relentless band of vicious raiders. The original gang’s firepower and grit is rekindled as they stand together against the onslaught of the ruthless bandits.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

19. Triple Cross (1966)

Triple Cross, “ set in World War II, tells the thrilling story of Eddie Chapman, a bank robber turned triple agent working for both the British and Germans. Christopher Plummer stars as Chapman, a skilled but dangerous spy whose actions threaten to sabotage the Allies’ war effort.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

20. Cast a Giant Shadow (1966)

Cast a Giant Shadow” is a gripping film set in the turbulent year of 1947, as the world awaits the decision to split British Palestine into Jewish and Arab states. The movie centers around a former U. S. Army officer who is brought on board by the Jews to reorganize the Haganah, a paramilitary organization. The film takes its viewers on an intense journey through the early days of the Israeli army, providing an up-close look at the challenges they faced during the 1948 Arab-Israeli War.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

21. The Double Man (1967)

The Double Man is a riveting 1967 thriller film that takes you on a suspense-filled journey into the world of espionage and double-crossing. Directed by Franklin J. Schaffner, this drama movie stars Yul Brynner, Britt Ekland, and Clive Revill. The story revolves around the Russian secret service making an attempt to kidnap a top-ranking CIA officer and replace him with their own double.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

22. The Long Duel (1967)

The Long Duel, “ set in 1967, is an action-packed, adventure-filled drama that explores the struggles of a tribal leader against British oppression. The film stars Yul Brynner, Trevor Howard, and Harry Andrews, with a compelling script penned by Peter Yeldham, Ranveer Singh, and Ernest Borneman, and directed by Ken Annakin.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

23. Villa Rides (1968)

Villa Rides, “ released in 1968, is an epic Western drama set in Mexico, where legendary rebel Pancho Villa leads a revolution. The plot thickens when a daring American aviator, who finds himself behind bars in Mexico, joins the rebellion.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

24. The Madwoman of Chaillot (1969)

The Madwoman of Chaillot” is a captivating comedy-drama film, released in 1969 and directed by Bryan Forbes. This masterpiece, featuring the talented Katharine Hepburn, Charles Boyer, and Claude Dauphin, provides a delightful portrayal of a class conflict-ridden society.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

25. The Battle of Neretva (1969)

The Battle of Neretva, “ an epic war drama directed by Veljko Bulajic, takes viewers to the heart of World War II. The film centers around the 1943 conflict that took place around the Neretva River in Yugoslavia. As Axis forces bore down on the Yugoslav partisan units, the story unfolds on a battlefield steeped in history and valor.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

26. The File of the Golden Goose (1969)

The File of the Golden Goose” is a thrilling 1969 action-crime drama that follows U. S. Agent Novak and Scotland Yard Officer Thompson as they infiltrate a dangerous counterfeit organization. Set in an era of intrigue and deception, these two undercover agents find themselves navigating through the dangerous world of casinos, roulette tables, pool tables, and cigar-smoking criminals.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

27. The Magic Christian (1969)

Experience the whimsical world of “The Magic Christian” (1969), a delightful movie that explores the depths of human vanity and greed. The film stars the iconic Peter Sellers, Ringo Starr, and Isabel Jeans in a light-hearted comedy about the wealthy aristocrat Guy Grand and his adopted hobo son, Simon Grand.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

28. The Lady in the Car with Glasses and a Gun (1970)

The Lady in the Car with Glasses and a Gun is a suspenseful drama from 1970, filled with intriguing twists and turns. Directed by Anatole Litvak, this film follows the story of a secretary who takes her boss’s car for a vacation in the Mediterranean. However, things take an unexpected turn when she retraces a journey she has never taken before and finds herself recognized by strangers.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

29. Catlow (1971)

In the thrilling 1971 Western comedy “Catlow, “ the notorious outlaw, played by Yul Brynner, embarks on a daring journey to Hermosillo, Mexico, to carry out a $2,000,000 gold heist. As we follow him through the scorching Sonora desert of Mexico, we find him trying to dodge interference from various lawmen across Arizona and Tucson.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

30. The Light at the Edge of the World (1971)

Experience the thrilling adventure of “The Light at the Edge of the World, “ released in 1971. Set in the late 18th century, this gripping tale pits the ruthless pirate Captain Baldo, played by Yul Brynner, against the brave lighthouse keeper. Baldo aims to manipulate the lighthouse signals to destroy any ships approaching the southernmost city in Argentina. As the desperate lighthouse keeper tries to resist Baldo’s torture, the fate of countless lives depends on their will to prevail.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

31. Romance of a Horsethief (1971)

Romance of a Horsethief is a historical drama that takes place in 1905, near the Russian border in a village inhabited by Polish horse thieves, whose livelihood is under threat due to the Russo-Japanese conflict. The Russian army confiscates all horses and conscripts all men, disrupting their lifestyle. The film follows the lives of these horse thieves, focusing on their struggle to survive and adapt in this challenging environment.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

32. Fuzz (1972)

Fuzz” is a thrilling, action-packed comedy that takes place in 1972 Boston, where the city is terrorized by a notorious master criminal. This unidentified bomber is trying to extort money from the city using fear and blackmail. Enter the tough, street-smart detective, Jack Weston (Jack Weston), and the beautiful, cunning policewoman, Lily Dillon (Raquel Welch), who are determined to find the bomber and put an end to his nefarious schemes.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

33. The Serpent (1973)

The Serpent” (1973), directed by Henri Verneuil, is a thrilling drama-thriller that transports audiences into the tense world of Soviet espionage. The film follows a Soviet diplomat, played by Yul Brynner, who unravels a complex plan to defect from East to West.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

34. Westworld (1973)

Westworld” is a gripping 1973 sci-fi thriller, directed by the iconic Michael Crichton, who also penned the original screenplay. With a runtime of 1 hour and 28 minutes, this movie packs a punch that is sure to leave audiences on the edge of their seats.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

35. The Ultimate Warrior (1975)

The Ultimate Warrior, “ a 1975 low-budget sci-fi action film directed by Robert Clouse, is set in a dystopian future of New York City. In this plague-ridden world, Yul Brynner plays a weary hero who discovers the will to fight when his life takes an unexpected turn. Joining him in this harrowing journey are Max von Sydow and Joanna Miles, adding depth to the film’s gritty intensity.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

36. Futureworld (1976)

Futureworld” is an intriguing blend of sci-fi and thriller, released in 1976. When an ex-employee of a futuristic theme-park stumbles upon a dark conspiracy involving robots and the laboratory, they are tragically murdered.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

37. It’s Showtime (1976)

It’s Showtime” is a delightful 1976 documentary that takes audiences on a heartwarming journey through the world of animal acting. The film weaves together an enchanting array of clips, showcasing the incredible talent and camaraderie that exists between animals and their human co-stars.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

38. Death Rage (1976)

Set in the gritty world of crime and vengeance, Death Rage (1976), also known as Con la rabbia agli occhi, follows a retired hitman as he’s coerced into taking one final job — an act of revenge against the mafia gang responsible for the brutal murder of his brother. As he embarks on this harrowing mission, he is aided by a young, ambitious mobster eager to prove himself.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

39. The Royal Variety Performance 1979 (1979)

Experience the magic of music and comedy as you journey back to 1979 with The Royal Variety Performance 1979. This captivating television special is a true celebration of talent, as it showcases the performances of some of the most iconic artists of the era.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

40. Night of 100 Stars II (1985)

Step into a world of glamour, laughter, and song! . “Night of 100 Stars II” is a 1985 television special that combines the genres of comedy, family, and music. An impressive array of stars, including Debbie Allen, Peter Allen, and Harry Anderson, come together in this heartwarming celebration of entertainment.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

41. Hollywood Heaven: Tragic Lives, Tragic Deaths (1990)

Hollywood Heaven: Tragic Lives, Tragic Deaths” (1990) is an intense and poignant documentary featuring a compelling compilation of photos, footage, and trailers, exploring the lives and untimely deaths of various well-known stars. With a runtime of 1 hour and 40 minutes, this film delves into the tragic stories that unfolded off-screen, providing an intimate glimpse into the lives of the fallen.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

42. Rodgers & Hammerstein: The Sound of Movies (1996)

Rodgers & Hammerstein: The Sound of Movies” is a captivating documentary that delves into the world of the legendary songwriting duo, Richard Rodgers and Lorenz Hart. The film offers a unique exploration of their incredible musical journey and their impact on the world of cinema.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

43. Welcome to Woop Woop (1997)

In the quirky and whimsical world of “Welcome to Woop Woop, “ a sly con artist finds himself in the Australian outback, far from his New York troubles. As he’s welcomed into the peculiar town and its idiosyncratic inhabitants, he begins to dabble in their oddball ways. But things take a turn for the unexpected, as a series of strange encounters and captivating situations unfold, each with its own unique twists and turns.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

44. Anita no perd el tren (2001)

In the heartwarming Spanish comedy “Anita no perd el tren” (2001), Anita has spent 30 years working at a local cinema, but finds herself out of work when the theater is demolished to make way for a shopping complex. Unable to adjust to the new company’s image, Anita is forced into early retirement — but she isn’t ready to give up without a fight.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

45. Cleopatra: The Film That Changed Hollywood (2001)

Cleopatra: The Film That Changed Hollywood” is a gripping documentary that delves into the making of this iconic film and offers a fascinating look at the challenges that faced the movie industry as it unfolded. This captivating film explores the idiosyncrasies, difficulties, and intrigues that surrounded the production of the blockbuster. The film takes viewers on an enchanting journey through the making of a film that changed the face of Hollywood forever.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

46. Meine Schwester Maria (2002)

Meine Schwester Maria” is a heartfelt journey that takes viewers into the lives of two extraordinary siblings. Famous Hollywood actor Maximilian Schell provides a tender portrayal of his sister, the equally renowned Maria, in this captivating documentary. The film’s narrative unfolds as Maximilian explores his sister’s life, talent, and legacy, delving into the strong bond they share.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

47. Filmmakers vs. Tycoons (2005)

Filmmakers vs. Tycoons” (2005) is a Spanish documentary that explores the impact of the film industry on the creative process.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

48. Eurocrime! The Italian Cop and Gangster Films That Ruled the ’70s (2012)

Eurocrime! . The Italian Cop and Gangster Films That Ruled the ‘70s” is a captivating documentary that delves into the thrilling and often brutal Italian ‘poliziotteschi’ films of the 1970s.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

49. I Am Steve McQueen (2014)

I Am Steve McQueen” is a captivating documentary that delves into the life and legacy of the iconic American actor, motor sports enthusiast, and charismatic personality, Steve McQueen. Directed by Jeff Renfroe and written by David Ray, this documentary is an intimate look at the man behind the screen, told through the perspectives of those who knew him best. It features interviews with McQueen’s family, including his son, Chad, his grandson, Steven, and his granddaughter, Molly, as well as former wives Neile Adams McQueen, Ali MacGraw, and his widow. The film captures the essence of McQueen’s talent, charm, and enduring impact on both the entertainment industry and motorsports.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

50. Ingrid Bergman: In Her Own Words (2015)

Ingrid Bergman: In Her Own Words” takes a captivating and intimate look at the life of a young Swedish girl who rose to become one of the most celebrated actresses in both American and World cinema. Directed by Stig Björkman, this compelling documentary features archive footage of the iconic star, revealing the world behind the camera and offering a unique glimpse into her personal life and relationships. The film also includes interviews with those closest to her, such as her daughter Pia Lindström, and explores her remarkable journey from humble beginnings in Sweden to Hollywood stardom.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

That’s All Folks!
